Graphical abstract The introduction of exfoliated graphite into pelletized Co-based catalysts affects in the most positive way both catalytic and physico-chemical properties. Unlike other carbons, the exfoliated graphite allows combination of extended surface with high thermal conductivity. An open-ended system of slit-type pores is revealed by X-ray tomography. Electron microscopy shows graphitic platelets forming an all-penetrating heat-conductive frame. Element distribution analysis shows that this catalyst cannot be considered as a cobalt-on-carbon catalyst since the graphitic component carries insignificant amount of cobalt and serves as a heat-conductive frame only. Thermal conductivity of a catalyst with graphite frame is 2 times higher than that of its industrial predecessor with Al metal frame and 30 times higher than that of a catalyst without heat-conductive additive. Testing in exothermal Fischer–Tropsch synthesis shows a favorable influence of the graphitic additive, i.e. such catalyst shows productivity of 455 g/kg/h at GHSV of 3000 h−1. Keywords Catalyst Fischer-tropsch synthesis Thermal conductivity Exfoliated graphite Aluminum Cobalt 1 Introduction Low-temperature Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is known as a highly exothermic catalytic process (146–176 kJ per 1 mol of CO) for production of liquid hydrocarbons mixture from CO and H2 over Co-based catalysts [1]. Co-based catalysts require precision in controlling the process temperature because uneven temperature distribution and local overheats shift the reaction conditions out of the narrow FTS range leading to intensive formation of methane by direct CO hydrogenation and to accelerated deactivation of the catalyst [2–6]. The reaction temperature control in a heterogeneous fixed bed as a key factor for any prospective highly productive catalytic system may become possible if an efficient heat removal is arranged. The conventional catalysts contain usually 15–30 wt.% of cobalt often promoted by noble metals [7–10]. A support should be characterized by high enough surface area, mechanical strength and durability under hydrothermal conditions. Conventional FTS catalysts produced by impregnation of alumina, silica or titania with cobalt salt solutions have been thoroughly investigated by the moment, so their structure, morphology and active center behavior are commonly known. The removal of FTS-generated heat from such ceramic pelletized catalysts is limited, which is a reason for more attention to the problem of thermal conductivity of a support in recent research [3,5,11–14]. It is especially important for zeolite-containing hybrid catalysts [15]. One should note however that a heat-conductive frame of a support is not the only way for FTS-generated heat to leave a catalyst pellet. The removal of reaction products from the pellet through its pore system (especially meso- and macro-pores) is also important [11,12]. So the efficient mass transport is crucial especially taking into account the fact that while the reactants enter the catalytic bed in gaseous form the products are mostly liquid and hence experience diffusion limitations in transport [2,13,12–14]. The materials with hierarchical porosity are very attractive for such catalytic processes because different pores provide different important functions such as high surface area of micro/meso-pores for fixation of active centers or mass transfer to the outer limits of the pellet by macro-pores [16,17]. Unfortunately, high porosity and high surface area are accompanied with quite poor thermal conductivity, which kills the positive effect achieved by the porous system. The use of monolithic supports (cordierite or γ–Al2O3 or steel or iron-chromium alloy or aluminum or carbon) or foams (silicon carbide or aluminum) is often considered as a good way for intensification of heat- and mass transfer [3,11,13,14,18–20]. Another promising technique is introduction of a heat-conductive additive into conventional support material while a catalyst is in preparation. The microfibers (copper or aluminum) or powders (aluminum or copper or zinc or carbon) were suggested as such additives [5,12,14,21–23]. It is important that a catalytic bed comprising the aluminum powder-doped pellets showed a three-fold productivity jump as compared with conventional pelletized fixed bed [12,23]. Another popular direction of development is the use of heat-conductive carbons as supports for cobalt. There are reports on the use of various carbons such as carbon nanotubes, graphitized carbon, non-porous carbon spheres, graphite, graphene oxide, activated charcoal and nanoporous graphene in the literature [24–33]. Other reasons for the use of carbon supports in FTS catalysts include weak metal-carbon interaction, which allow easy activation and higher catalytic activity as a result. However the carbon supports often bring lower C5+ selectivity because of support role in gasification reactions, which leads to higher yield of undesirable CH4 and CO2 [22]. Another drawback is catalyst manufacturing complications, which often include sophisticated encapsulation of cobalt nanoparticles with carbon and lead to irreproducible properties of the catalyst. One can observe that the main problem is a contradiction between high thermal conductivity requirement, which is met by highly crystallized graphite only, and high surface/porosity requirement, which is met by poorly crystallized or amorphous carbons. Moreover, high thermal conductivity is usually coupled with durability to gasification, i.e. durability to the involvement into reactions with FTS environment components (H2, CO2, H2O), which might lead to significant or even complete loss of the carbon support. Taking into account the above-mentioned contradiction, a new type of nanostructured graphite namely exfoliated graphite nano-platelets (xGnP) or graphene may present interest as a prospective heat-conductive component for FTS catalysts. The xGnP has a foam-like structure as demonstrated in Fig. 1 . Highly crystallized natural graphite serves as a precursor for xGnP production. Oxidative intercalation in graphite followed by explosive de-intercalation leads to exfoliation of bulk graphite crystals into thin ribbon-like packs, which comprise very limited number of graphenes each and represent shards of a precursor large graphite crystal. As a result, a low-density highly-porous crumpled xGnP structure is formed [34]. It is remarkable that high porosity is combined here with very high crystallinity inherited from a precursor graphite. It was recently reported that a pelletized catalyst with exfoliated graphite-based heat-conductive frame was issued by OOO INFRA as a commercial product [35,36]. The purpose of this paper was to report a new pelletized FTS catalyst with a heat-conductive frame made of exfoliated graphite and to investigate some properties of it. The research was focused on step-by-step comparison with the earlier discovered predecessor catalyst [12, 23, 37] using aluminum metal powder in its heat-conductive frame. It is necessary to note that a comparison of catalytic properties of industry-targeted pelletized catalysts is inevitably reported as results produced at so called optimum conditions i.e. in a fixed pelletized bed at the temperature, which provides the best combination of conversion and C5+ selectivity (meaning the highest possible productivity of the bed) at a fixed GHSV. 2 Experimental The supports were prepared by mixing heat-conductive component (exfoliated graphite (UNICHIMTEK) or aluminum metal powder (PAP-2 grade by RUSAL)), H-Beta zeolite (Zeolyst, SiO2/Al2O3 = 38) and boehmite (Sasol) as a binder with the liquid phase comprising a mixture of 9.4 % HNO3, triethyleneglycol and C2H5OH (Table 1 ) until a homogenized paste was formed. The relative concentrations of liquid phase are disclosed in [35]. The reference sample, prepared for comparative FTS activity test, did not contain a heat-conductive component. As soon as the paste homogeneity was reached it was formed by a piston extruder through a 1.5–2.5 mm diameter die. Then the extrudates were dried, calcined and cut to pellets of 2–3 mm length. Fabricated supports have the form of pellets of structured porous composite material, the pellets have size of 2.5 × 2.5 mm for CoAl, 1.5 × 2 mm for CoG and 2.5 × 3 for Ref sample. Exfoliated graphite was supplied by UNICHIMTEK as “Thermally expanded graphite (Natural scaly graphite” TRG-50/4 in the form of lightweight flaky powder with density when delivered 12 g/l. TRG-50/4 represents immediate precursor of graphitic foil grade C, i.e. it is a powder just before rolling into a foil. Specification stipulates the same chemical composition as for grade C foil, in particular carbon content >99.5 %. Cobalt was used as an active component in FTS. All catalysts were prepared by two-step incipient wetness impregnation of supports with water solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, every step was followed by calcination in air flow at 250 °C for 1 h. Cobalt loading was 20 wt.% calculated on support weight. CoAl and Ref catalysts were prepared according to the techniques described in detail elsewhere [12,23]. The new catalyst with exfoliated graphite was prepared according to [35]. In addition to CoAl, CoG and Ref catalyst samples, there were model systems prepared by wet impregnation of aluminum metal powder (Co/Al) or exfoliated graphite (Co/G) with the sole purpose to compare cobalt distribution on the surface of the heat-conductive frame. The study of catalytic properties is given here as a comparison of industry-targeted pelletized catalysts and reports as such the results produced at so called optimum conditions i.e. in a fixed pelletized bed at the temperature, which provides the best combination of conversion and C5+ selectivity (meaning the highest possible productivity of the bed) at a fixed GHSV. The Fischer–Tropsch synthesis was carried out in a steel fixed-bed tubular reactor with 10 mm inner diameter, catalyst loading was 2.5 cm3. CoAl catalyst loading was 1.66 g, CoG — 1.52 g and Ref — 1.97 g. The catalyst was activated in pure hydrogen before synthesis; the hydrogen was supplied at gas-hour space velocity (GHSV) of 3000 h−1 at 400 °C and 0.1 MPa for 1 h. GHSV was calculated at the reactor outlet at room temperature and atmosphere pressure conditions. Catalyst degree of reduction was estimated by oxygen titration as 40–50 %. After activation the catalyst was heated in synthesis gas stream at 2 MPa, raising the temperature from 170 to 220–235 °C by 3–10 °C steps every 6 h. Synthesis gas (molar ratio H2/CO = 2 with 5 vol.% of N2 as balance and internal reference) was supplied at 1000 h−1 GHSV while the temperature was raised and optimized (until reaching the maximum possible C5+ hydrocarbons productivity). The reactor was run for 36–42 h before the steady state. Then the GHSV was increased stepwise to 3000 h−1 and the temperature was optimized for every GHSV. Composition of gaseous and liquid products was determined chromatographically. The analysis of feed mixture and gaseous products (CH4, CO2, C2–C4 hydrocarbons) was performed by gas adsorption chromatography (thermal conductivity detector, carrier gas — helium, gas flow rate 20 mL/min). The column with CaA molecular sieves (3 m × 3 mm) was used to separate CO and CH4. The HayeSep column (3 m × 3 mm) was used to separate CO2 and C2–C4 hydrocarbons. The temperature-programmed mode was used (60–200 °C, heating rate 10 °C/min). Material balance was calculated on a daily basis. Material balance closure was at least 98 %. Composition of C5+ hydrocarbons was determined by gas-liquid chromatography (flame ionization detector, carrier gas — helium, gas flow rate 30 mL/min). The 50 m length capillary column with DP-Petro plate was used. The temperature-programmed mode was used (50–270 °C, heating rate 4 °C/min). Carbon chain growth probability was calculated from Anderson–Schultz–Flory molecular-mass distribution according to Flory equation: Wn = (1–α)2 × nα n –1, where α — chain growth probability; Wn — mass content of n-paraffin with carbon number n obtained from chromatogram. The material balance was composed after each change in the synthesis conditions (temperature or flow rate) for 25 days, and reproducibility of measurements was ≥98 %. Thermal conductivity was measured for cylindrical pellets, every measurement was repeated at 10 independent samples in order to minimize data scattering, which, however, never exceeded 2%. In order to receive the value of thermal conductivity, it was necessary to measure heat capacity and temperature conductivity and then calculate the thermal conductivity value according to the formula λ = α × Cp × ρ, where ρ — apparent density calculated from geometric parameters of a sample, kg/m3; α — temperature conductivity, m2/s; Cp — heat capacity, J/(kg K). Heat capacity was measured by calorimetry at DSC8000 (PerkinElmer). The temperature conductivity was measured by laser flash method at LFA 457/2/G MicroFlash analyzer (NETZSCH). The electron microscopy study of the samples of heat-conductive additives, supports and catalysts were carried out on scanning electron microscopes VEGA 3 (TESCAN) and JSM-7600 F (JEOL) and on the transmission electron microscope JEM-2010 (JEOL) equipped with the EELS and EDS attachments. Temperature-programmed reduction investigations were carried out at Autosorb-1C (Quantachrome Instruments). Structural characteristics of the porous systems of the supports and catalysts were obtained by NOVA 1200e (Quantachrome Instruments). XRD analysis was performed at 25 °C with the purpose to estimate cobalt crystallite size on Empyrean Panalytical Diffractometer (Cu-Kα radiation, Bragg-Brentano HD module as monochromator, solid state semiconductor Pixel3D detector). Thermal analysis in oxidizing atmosphere (synthetic air) was performed for the catalysts before and after FTS tests on a STA 449 F1 (Netzsch) equipped with an analyzer of evolved gases and quadrupole mass analyzer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of heat-conductive additives Fig. 2 demonstrates SEM images of the heat-conductive additives used. In both images the particles of sophisticated morphology can be seen. In case of exfoliated graphite a typical size of the particle is 150 × 300 × 160 μm3; while in case of aluminum metal powder it is 20 × 30 × 1 μm3. Aluminum metal powder is distinguished as flat flakes (Fig. 2a), while exfoliated graphite has an inherent bulk folded structure (Fig. 2b). The morphology of the heat-conductive component plays an important role in creating the heat-conductive frame in the support. 3.2 Characterization of CoAl and CoG supports SEM images of support pellet shear surface (end cleavage) shown in Fig. 3 manifest a kind of planet-in-the-space view with aluminum or graphite flakes looking like long clouds. This witnesses that the pellets have well-developed porosity and extended surface. The introduction of a heat-conductive additive brings specific texture and forms a heat-conducting frame. One can see macropores and the heat-conducting frame comprised of aluminum metal flakes in Fig. 3a. The exfoliated graphite-based sample displays crumbly macroporous structure with clearly seen transport pore system (Fig. 3b). The data on structural properties of investigated supports are given in Table 2 . Surface area and pore volume vary according to the type of heat-conductive additive. Aluminum-based sample is characterized by larger pore volume and graphite-based one demonstrates extended surface area. Results on structural properties of supports pore system are in agreement with pellets surface SEM images (Fig. 3). 3.3 Characterization of CoAl and CoG catalysts and the impact of catalytic testing Fig. 4 demonstrates SEM images of CoAl and CoG catalysts surface. It is clearly seen that the composite texture depends on type of heat-conductive additive. The surface structure of CoAl catalyst (Fig. 4a) is formed by parallel shiny flakes of aluminum metal with zeolite and binder particles between and around the heat-conductive frame. The total surface of catalyst pellet obtained by impregnation is covered by cobalt oxide particles that impart a dull tint to the photograph. One can observe large transport mesopores diverging along the pellet in all directions, which suggests through porosity. The surface of CoG sample does not possess the brightness specific to aluminum metal flakes (Fig. 4b). The composite is characterized by a larger three-dimensional porous system, penetrating the pellet surface in all directions. The heat-conducting frame formed by particles of exfoliated graphite is visible in the form of a lattice. Structural properties of the catalysts are given in Table 3 . Impregnation of support with active metal (20 wt.% of cobalt) leads to decrease in composite surface area, which is to be expected. Graphite-based sample exhibits more developed surface area. Catalyst pore volume is 0.35–0.39 cm3/g. Data on catalyst thermal conductivity prove that the introduction of aluminum metal powder as well as the introduction of exfoliated graphite provides the formation of effective heat-conductive frame. In contrast, thermal conductivity of a Ref pellet, which does not contain heat-conductive additive (80 wt.% of zeolite and 20 wt.% of binder) is 0.25 W/m K only. It is remarkable that just 20 % weight of exfoliated graphite gives thermal conductivity twice as high as in case of 50 % weight of aluminum in CoAl sample. The visualization of cross-sections of a catalyst pellet obtained by X-ray tomography (Fig. 5 ) confirms the above assumption that the pellets feature developed through porosity in every direction that in turn ensures effective mass transport properties during FTS. CoG catalyst is characterized by even more developed interconnecting pore system and transport channels, which penetrate the pellet in every direction. In addition, the pores of CoG are predominantly slit-type. Fig. 6 demonstrates element mapping of the CoAl catalyst surface linked to SEM image. Elemental analysis was carried out with EDS attachment for this particular surface section. One can see an aluminum metal flake, which dominates the image of Fig. 6. Al-atoms in surrounding areas are explained by the presence of binder and zeolite. Si-atoms distribution map, which represents zeolite localization only, evidences that zeolite particles are concentrated predominately around the aluminum flake and only a small part of them are placed directly on flake surface. O-atoms are distributed evenly enough, however their localization does not give us significant information, since this element is a part of zeolite, binder, cobalt oxides and oxide coating on aluminum metal flake surface. Co-atoms distribution indicates that catalytically active phase is allocated evenly enough over the support surface. However, one can observe directly on the surface of aluminum flake a local minimum in density distribution, but it is not as significant as in case of Si-atoms. The element mapping of the CoG catalyst surface linked to SEM image presented in Fig. 7 manifests a frontal platelet of exfoliated graphite stack in the middle of the image (C-atoms mapping). Al-atoms are located on the platelet sidewall and around it and indicate distribution of binder and zeolite. The arrangement of O-atoms with slight differences follows the pattern of the mapping of aluminum. Co-atoms distribution indicates that the cobalt-containing phase is localized predominantly above the oxygen- and aluminum-containing phases. The density of Co-atoms on the carbon surface is very low. It proves that the CoG catalyst cannot be considered as cobalt-on-carbon catalyst since the graphitic component carries insignificant amount of cobalt and serves as a heat-conductive frame only. The cobalt-containing phases of investigated catalysts are discerned as crystallites and agglomerates according to the data of TEM microscopy (Fig. 8 ). Cobalt oxide crystallites formed in the presence of both CoAl and CoG catalysts are described by similar particle size of 10–15 nm averagely. The data on crystallite size are confirmed by XRD analysis. The average cobalt oxide crystallite size for CoAl sample is 17 nm as determined by XRD peak profile analysis. CoG sample is characterized by 13 nm average crystallite size. The impact of catalytic testing on the properties of both CoAl and CoG testing was studied at the samples kindly provided by OOO INFRA after scale-up runs. It is important to analyze the effect of catalytic tests on the cobalt-containing phase particle size and on the patterns of thermal analysis, which reflect the appearance of new after-test deposits. TEM images (Fig. 9 ) evidence that 50 -h catalytic run leads to enlargement of cobalt oxide crystallites up to 20–60 nm. This fact can be explained by formation of catalyst stable surface during its activation. The CoG catalyst is characterized by noticeably larger crystallites size of 30 nm average, confirmed by XRD peak profile analysis. It is that longer catalytic run time up to 2000 h revealed no further enlargement of crystallites size both for CoAl (reported elsewhere [23]) and CoG. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) curves of investigated catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 . The type and shape of the curves depend on the nature of heat-conductive additive. It is known that melting of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O succeeded by gradual dehydration leads to formation of anhydrous Co(NO3)2 which is further decomposed to Cо2O3. At the temperatures around 180 °C Cо2O3 begins to form Cо3O4 phase. In addition to the processes described above, the catalyst undergoes various transformations, which include interaction of the cobalt-containing compounds with the surface of support. These surface processes cause the appearance of a shoulder in TPR curve at 280–320 °C for CoG catalyst, in particular the most important process is the reduction of stainierite phase, which was formed by Cо2O3 immobilization by surface hydroxyls. CoO phase, which is a result of such partial reduction, forms bulk Co3O4 by interaction with residual Cо2O3. In the case of CoAl one can observe significant decrease in the intensity of TPR curve at temperatures below 340 °C accompanied by almost complete disappearance of stainierite phase. The reason for that is Cо2O3 reduction to Cо3O4 at the early stage of catalyst formation due to the use of more organic components for paste formation. Hydrogen consumption at temperatures of 350–360оC and 380оC, as well as shoulders at 420–480о observed in TPR curves characterize the continuing gradual reduction of the bulk Co3O4 phase to form CoO crystallites and CoO–Cо3O4 solid solution. The phase of agglomerated CoO–Cо3O4 solid solution is reduced showing a broad peak at 350−500 °C. The total reduction peak at 400–420 °C is caused by bulky CoO crystallites transformation to cobalt metal. The broad maximum at temperatures of 480–600 °C corresponds to reduction of multilayer cobalt oxide phases, which are immobilized at the surface of support. The CoAl does not manifest this peak because of hydrogen release in the same temperature range, which is caused by residual organics thermolysis. Aluminum metal melting induces intensive release of hydrogen, which is reflected as a narrow reverse peak at 650–680 °C. The shift in the maximum of high-temperature peak in TPR curve for CoG catalyst indicates that the binder and its intermediate products of thermolysis significantly affect the formation of cobalt aluminates. Moreover, such high-temperature peak is derived from reduction of not only near-surface structures of defective cobalt-containing spinel, but also from reduction of other crystallized bulk structures. Octahedrally coordinated cobalt is reduced at the temperatures of 450–650 °C while tetrahedrally coordinated one — at 680–800 °C. The data obtained from TPR of catalysts indicate that the type of heat-conductive additive affects the nature of active metal interaction with the surface of support. The resulting cobalt oxides crystallites can vary in composition and size. The TG and DTA curves obtained during thermal analysis of CoAl and CoG catalysts before catalytic tests are presented in Fig. 11 . The TG curve of the CoAl sample (Fig. 11a) exhibits effects associated both with a decrease and an increase in the weight of the catalyst. The first peak arises from the loss of water as evidenced by the data obtained by analysis of the evolved gases. The second peak is caused by oxidation of aluminum metal. The narrow endothermal effect at 620–660 °C in the DTA curve corresponds to melting of aluminum metal, while the exothermal effects at 500–620 and 800–1000 °C correspond to the metal oxidation. It means that some aluminum metal particles start oxidation and melting earlier due to defects in their protective coatings. Then aluminum particles melt, become spherical, the surface area decreases dramatically, and, as a result, the rate of aluminum metal oxidation decreases. Temperature increase provides continued oxidation that ends with alumina formation. It is practically important to prove that the oxidation of aluminum metal begins below the melting temperature since that oxidation leads to destruction of the entire catalyst. This information makes it possible to establish a range of safe operating temperatures for the CoAl catalyst. The TG curve of the CoG sample (Fig. 11b) exhibits effects associated with catalyst weight decrease. Stepless weight loss from the beginning of the analysis up to 500 °C is caused by loss of water as evidenced by the data obtained by the evolved gas analysis. Further dramatic weight loss is associated with graphite oxidation accompanied with CO2 release. The broad exothermal peak at 600–800 °C corresponds to gradual oxidation of graphite. Fig. 12 represents 3D mass-spectra and their 2D cross-section for m/z 18 (water) of CoAl catalyst before catalytic tests. 3D mass-spectra display the evolution of response intensity in the temperature range up to 1200 °C for different m/z numbers (Fig. 12a). The curve reflects two main effects. The peak observed at temperatures up to 200 °C corresponds to plasticizer (TEG) decomposition with the release of CO and water at m/z of 14 and 18, respectively. Intensive water release is also observed at higher temperatures, presumably indicating dehydration processes. Fig. 12b demonstrates the dependence of response intensity on temperature for parent mass peak with m/z = 18, which corresponds to positively charged water ion. It is evident that CoAl catalyst sample loses water over the entire temperature range. Fig. 13 a represents 3D mass-spectra, which display the evolution of response intensity at the temperatures up to 1200 °C for different m/z masses of CoG catalyst before catalytic tests. The dependence of response intensity on temperature for parent mass peak with m/z = 44, which corresponds to CO2 release, is represented in Fig. 13b. Carbon dioxide emission proceeds in two steps. The broad indistinct peak in low temperature region (200–440 °C) is compliant with plasticizer (TEG) decomposition and more distinct high-temperature peak (550–800 °C) corresponds to oxidation of graphite. The TG and DTA curves obtained during thermal analysis of CoAl and CoG catalysts after catalytic tests are presented in Fig. 14 . The difference with the before-test result is revealed as an additional exothermal peak at 250–370 °C in DTA curve of CoAl catalyst (Fig. 14a), which is most probably associated with oxidation of carbon-containing compounds formed on the catalyst surface during FTS catalytic tests. The appearance of additional exothermal peak in DTA curve and respective effect of weight decrease in TG curve of CoG catalyst at 320–450 °C (Fig. 14b) can be also explained by oxidation of carbon-containing compounds formed on the catalyst surface during FTS catalytic tests. Fig. 15 represents 3D mass-spectra and 2D cross-section for mass number 44 of CoAl catalyst after catalytic tests. 3D mass-spectra display the evolution of response intensity in the temperature range up to 1200 °C for different m/z masses (Fig. 15a). Fig. 15b demonstrates the dependence of response intensity on temperature for parent mass peak with m/z = 44, referring to CO2 release. Carbon dioxide evolves in a narrow peak at 270–320 °C and corresponds to oxidation of carbon-containing compounds, which is consistent with exothermic peak in DTA curve of the sample (Fig. 14a). Fig. 16 a demonstrates 3D mass-spectra, which displays the evolution of response intensity in the temperature range up to 1200 °C for different m/z masses of CoG catalyst after catalytic tests. One can observe additional peaks around 400 °C with m/z masses 18 and 27. The dependence of response intensity on temperature for parent mass peak with m/z = 44, which corresponds to CO2 emission, is represented in Fig. 16b. Carbon dioxide emission proceeds in two steps in the same way as for catalyst sample before catalytic tests (Fig. 13b). However the intensity of low temperature peak increases significantly after catalytic testing, which could be explained by oxidation of carbon-containing compounds formed on the catalyst surface during FTS. The obtained data are in agreement with exothermic peak in DTA curve (Fig. 14b). 3.4 Cobalt on the surface of the heat-conductive frames Although it was shown above in this paper by element distribution analysis that CoG catalyst cannot be considered as a cobalt-on-carbon catalyst (since the graphitic component carries insignificant amount of cobalt and serves as a heat-conductive frame only), it is still interesting to investigate that insignificant cobalt deposited on the graphitic surface and compare with cobalt on aluminum metal flakes. The model systems of cobalt impregnated on aluminum metal powder (Co/Al) and on exfoliated graphite (Co/G) were studied to understand cobalt distribution on the heat-conductive frame surface. Fig. 17 demonstrate SEM image of Co/Al model system surface and its mapping of basic atoms obtained by elemental analysis with EDS attachment for this particular surface section. The data indicate that cobalt is distributed evenly enough over the metal surface. However some decrease in the density of the active metal atoms can be observed in the midst of large scale surface. Cobalt distribution on this model system surface is more uniform than on the surface of CoAl catalysts (Fig. 6). It is worth notice that the cobalt on aluminum metal flakes is actually linked to the surface aluminum oxide because no bare aluminum metal surface is possible in this kind of a system. The SEM image of the Co/G model system surface and its mapping of basic atoms presented in Fig. 18 indicate that cobalt distribution is not so uniform. It can be assumed that active metal tends to localization on end faces of exfoliated graphite platelets, which is in agreement with data obtained for graphite-containing catalyst (Fig. 7). According to TEM data (Fig. 19 ) cobalt-containing phase of aluminum-containing model system is dispersed to nano-crystallites. Such crystallites are evenly distributed through the outer surface of the flakes and arranged in clusters. The average size of an individual crystallite is about 5–10 nm. Fig. 20 demonstrates TEM images of exfoliated graphite surface with immobilized crystallites of cobalt oxides. It is obvious that crystallites are larger than that of Co/Al model system (Fig. 19). The average size of individual crystallite is about 20 nm. It is remarkable that the cobalt oxide crystallites form rather large island-like clusters made of small groups of cobalt oxides crystallites. Fig. 21 displays TPR curves of aluminum- and graphite-containing model systems. The data witness difference between these two heat-conductive additives in the nature of interaction with active metal. The main effect registered for Co/G model system is the reduction of macro-crystalline Cо3O4 that clearly indicates a very weak interaction of impregnated cobalt nitrate with the surface of exfoliated graphite. It is obvious that even in the composition of CoG catalyst the exfoliated graphite serves mainly as an additive that forms a heat-conductive frame while its interaction with cobalt-containing phases is negligible. At the same time for CoG catalyst (Fig. 10) most of cobalt captured during the reduction process is associated with unordered surface or bulk structures. Formation of such structures is determined by alumina component of the catalysts. 3.5 The results of catalytic testing The investigated catalysts were active in FTS. The main FTS parameters and composition of produced C5+ hydrocarbons (HCs) are given in the Tables 4 and 5 . The parameters for the Ref catalyst without heat-conductive additive are given as reference. The introduction of a heat-conductive frame into pellets resulted at 1000 h−1 in the increase of CO conversion from 72 for Ref up to 77–84 % for both CoAl and CoG. The selectivity of target product formation slightly decreased from 59 to 53–55 %. Methane selectivity increased from 17 to 21–22 % with the introduction of a heat-conductive frame regardless to its nature. CO2 selectivity increased from 5 to 12 %. The introduction of a heat-conductive additive increased the catalyst productivity at 1000 h−1 from 98 to 113–118 g/kg∙h. The reference catalyst was characterized by the following composition of the produced C5+ hydrocarbons: 23 % of olefins, 45 % of n-paraffins, 32 % of isoparaffins, chain growth probability (α) 0.77. The introduction of aluminum metal powder resulted in decrease of olefins content to 16 % and isoparaffins content to 28 % and increase of n-paraffins content up to 56 %. Chain growth probability slightly decreased to 0.75. The CoG catalyst generated C5+ hydrocarbons containing the lowest olefins content (8%) and the highest n-paraffins content (62 %). The content of isoparaffins was 30 % while the chain growth probability was 0.75. The increase of synthesis gas gas-hour space velocity (GHSV) up to 3000 h−1 revealed more significant differences among the investigated catalysts (Table 4,5). Thus, the introduction of heat-conductive additive allowed to increase significantly CO conversion from 47 % up to 71–81 %, target product selectivity — from 56 up to 66–69 %, and C5+ hydrocarbons productivity — from 190 up to 375–455 g/kg∙h. Methane selectivity decreased from 21 % for Ref to 17–18 % for CoG/CoAl, while CO2 selectivity was 2–3% regardless to the catalyst composition. The highest productivity was reached in the presence of exfoliated graphite-containing catalyst. The introduction of a heat-conductive frame resulted at 3000 h−1 in the increase of olefins content from 29 up to 30–38 %; also in the increase in n-paraffins from 32 up to 40–48 %, while the isoparaffins content decreased from 39 to 22 %. Chain growth probability slightly decreased to 0.73. The similar values of C5+ hydrocarbons, methane selectivity and CO2 selectivity in the presence of both aluminum- and graphite-containing catalysts support the mentioned above suggestion that graphic surface does not contribute in the FTS, i.e. the active cobalt is in very similar state in both CoAl and CoG catalysts. Moreover, both catalysts have similar deactivation behavior [37]. 4 Conclusion A new pelletized FTS catalyst with a heat-conductive frame made of exfoliated graphite was reported and investigated. The research was focused on step-by-step comparison with the earlier discovered predecessor catalyst with aluminum metal powder in its heat-conductive frame. The investigation of exfoliated graphite as a heat-conductive additive to pelletized Co catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis showed that the introduction of such additive influences most positively on both catalytic and physico-chemical properties of a catalyst. The exfoliated graphite-based support is characterized by extended surface, which affords impregnation with significant amounts of active metal. Unlike other carbon additives, the exfoliated graphite allows combination of extended surface with high thermal conductivity and durability to gasification. The flaky nature of exfoliated graphite leads to formation of open-ended transport pore system. As shown by X-ray tomography, such pores are predominantly slit-type, which is favorable for the transport of FTS products such as liquid hydrocarbons and water. Electron microscopy data support the direct thermal conductivity measurements in conclusion of formation of all-penetrating heat-conductive frame made of graphitic platelets. Thermal conductivity of a catalyst with exfoliated graphite frame is 2 times higher than that of a catalyst with aluminum metal frame and 30 times higher than that of a catalyst without heat-conducting additives. Element distribution analysis shows that this catalyst cannot be considered as a cobalt-on-carbon catalyst since the graphitic component carries insignificant amount of cobalt and serves as a heat-conductive frame only. Thermal analysis of the catalysts revealed an advantage of the catalyst with exfoliated graphite frame in thermal stability. Indeed, this catalyst survives any overheats while the aluminum metal-based counterpart is limited by 450 °C or even lower because of irreversible effects related with aluminum metal pre-melting and oxidation. Testing under FTS conditions showed that the introduction of a heat-conductive additive improves catalytic properties significantly. A favorable influence of higher thermal conductivity of a pellet is first of all revealed by much higher allowable GHSV (or shorter contact time). The catalyst with exfoliated graphite frame shows productivity of 455 g/kg/h at elevated GHSV of 3000 h−1. coredata.dc:description: The introduction of exfoliated graphite into pelletized Co-based catalysts affects in the most positive way both catalytic and physico-chemical properties. Unlike other carbons, the exfoliated graphite allows combination of extended surface with high thermal conductivity. An open-ended system of slit-type pores is revealed by X-ray tomography. Electron microscopy shows graphitic platelets forming an all-penetrating heat-conductive frame. Element distribution analysis shows that this catalyst cannot be considered as a cobalt-on-carbon catalyst since the graphitic component carries insignificant amount of cobalt and serves as a heat-conductive frame only. Thermal conductivity of a catalyst with graphite frame is 2 times higher than that of its industrial predecessor with Al metal frame and 30 times higher than that of a catalyst without heat-conductive additive. Testing in exothermal Fischer–Tropsch synthesis shows a favorable influence of the graphitic additive, i.e. such catalyst shows productivity of 455 g/kg/h at GHSV of 3000 h−1.
coredata.dc:title: Exfoliated graphite as a heat-conductive frame for a new pelletized Fischer–Tropsch synthesis catalyst
